Award.AwardTitle: Portrait of a Community on the Threshold of Agriculture: The Late Natufian Zooarchaeological Assemblage from Nahal Ein Gev II, Israel

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project applies a high-resolution zooarchaeological approach to reconstruct the economic, social and ritual foundations of the forager-producer transition at the Terminal Pleistocene site of Nahal Ein Gev II in the Jordan Valley (Israel). Dr. Natalie Munro from the University of Connecticut will undertake zooarchaeological research in connection with the excavation of Nahal Ein Gev II, Israel by co-directors Prof. Ofer Bar-Yosef of Harvard University and Dr. Leore Grosman and Prof. Anna Belfer-Cohen of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Nahal Ein Gev II is a large Late Natufian village site occupied ca. 12,500-11,000 cal. BP and located about 2 km from the Sea of Galilee. The site's unusual temporal position at the very end of the Pleistocene, its geographic location in the productive Jordan Valley where farming communities first emerge in the region, and the large size and permanence of the village provide an ideal setting to investigate the interaction of human economy, community organization and ritual activity in the early stages of the unprecedented forager-producer transition.

Social theoretical approaches to agricultural origins increasingly diverge from economic explanations. Nevertheless, research increasingly shows that social, ritual and economic change are closely integrated across this long transition. Instead of searching for which came first, economic or social change, this research seeks to reconstruct and then integrate ecological, social and ritual conditions using the zooarchaeological record. The research focuses on six interrelated themes: environmental reconstruction, human foraging strategies, the meat diet, intra-community organization and the use of space, trash disposal practices, and ritual practice. Carbon and oxygen isotope analysis of gazelle tooth enamel carbonates will provide the environmental background to the site, while strontium isotopes taken from the same teeth will refine data on human hunting strategies, herd mobility and site seasonality. A detailed reconstruction of Terminal Pleistocene socioeconomics provides an essential foundation for understanding the rise of agricultural communities that followed.

This project aims to foster international collaboration through research exchanges involving faculty and students from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in Israel and the University of Connecticut in the United States. Exchanges are designed to deepen long-standing research collaborations between Munro and the Israeli project directors and extend these to the next generation of American and Israeli scholars. The research will provide hands on zooarchaeological training for both Israeli and American students who will engage in comprehensive zooarchaeological analysis.

The transition from foraging to agricultural communities marks one of, if not the foremost transformation in human history. The impact of this change was felt in all dimensions of human life. This research seeks to document the basal conditions and the societal transformations that comprise this irreversible change at one well-positioned settlement in the Jordan Valley.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Project Outcomes Report

 

The Project Outcomes Report serves as a brief summary, prepared specifically for the public, of the nature and outcomes of the NSF-funded project and is in addition to the final project report. The report must be submitted within the timeframe specified in the applicable award terms and conditions.

This project investigated the economic, social and ritual character of the Late Natufian (ca. 12,000 cal BP) community from Nahal Ein Gev II, Israel, on the eve of the transition to agriculture, using a high-resolution zooarchaeological data collection approach.

The research focused on five interconnected themes:

1. Reconstruction of local environmental conditions including seasonal variability.

2. The intensity of human hunting and it’s impacts on prey populations on local and regional scales.

3. Reconstruction of the meat diet and its preparation including carcass processing, cooking and consumption practices.

4. Identification of trash management strategies and activity areas such as carcass processing, food preparation and consumption, and disposal areas.

5. Investigation of community and ritual organization as viewed through the spatial analysis of faunal remains.

During the grant period a large dataset (8500 identifiable specimens) was collected from the skeletal remains of fauna recovered during eight seasons of excavation at Nahal Ein Gev II, a late hunter-gatherer site located 2 kilometers east of the Sea of Galilee in Israel. More than 100 gazelle and roe deer tooth samples were analyzed for oxygen, carbon, and strontium isotopes. In addition, burning and fragmentation data were collected on thousands of additional unidentifiable specimens.

Thus far data analysis has led to some key observations regarding the nature of human societies at the very beginning of the important transition to sedentary agricultural communities:

Specialized Aquatic Resource Exploitation: Aquatic resources including fish and waterfowl are more abundant at Nahal Ein Gev II than at most contemporary sites in the region. The focus on these smaller-bodied resources that require high technological investment for their capture, supports the hypothesis that Nahal Ein Gev II was intensively occupied, especially in comparison to Late Natufian sites in the adjacent Mediterranean Hills. More interesting is that despite the high natural diversity of aquatic resources in the Upper Jordan Valley, the residents from Nahal Ein Gev II targeted a narrow range of fish and waterfowl species. Nearly all of the more than 800 specimens of aquatic taxa in the assemblage derive from three species—two large Cyprinid fish and the greylag goose. These animals all fall at the large-bodied end of the aquatic resource spectrum. Thus, the foragers from Nahal Ein Gev II were highly selective—they captured only the largest, most cost-effective taxa, and transported the highest-utility body-parts to the site. The aquatic taxa provide clear evidence for often elusive task-specific activities—the residents of Nahal Ein Gev II made purposeful trips to the lake in certain seasons to engage in activities requiring special knowledge and experience. These observations complement technological evidence for other specialized activities at the site—a prelude to more specialized divisions of labor that emerge with fully agricultural communities.

Gazelle Hunting Territories: Results from oxygen, carbon and strontium stable isotope analysis of gazelle enamel carbonates, reveal that gazelles were locally hunted within five kilometers of Nahal Ein Gev II. This supports our hypothesis that the site was a more or less sedentary community with a defined territory. The result fits with other zooarchaeological evidence for intensive hunting, suggesting that density-dependent population effects were involved in the ensuing emergence of agriculture. Although, it is generally accepted that human population mobility increased in response to the Younger Dryas climatic event in the Mediterranean Hills region, our results suggest that conditions differed in the Jordan Valley. This is of special importance given that the first agricultural communities in the southern Levant likely arose Jordan Valley.

Community Organization and Waste Disposal: The transition to agriculture was intimately connected with sedentism—the settlement of more or less permanent villages. Features of community organization such as designated activity areas and formalized deposition practices are expected correlates of increased site permanence and more complex built environments. Preliminary spatial analysis of the Nahal Ein Gev II fauna reveals that the most discrete and unusual faunal deposits are found in the most clearly defined or protected features. The data suggest that some cleaning and spatially discrete activities occurred at the site, but in most cases, conclusive evidence for formalized waste disposal patterns is distiurbed by the movements of residents on site following trash deposition.

The results of this project contribute to current understanding of some of the most fundamental questions surrounding the origins of the economic and social organization of our modern human societies. In particular, this research contributes to understanding the conditions from which practices that are near universal today—human territoriality, waste disposal, and the management of domestic plants and animals—emerged.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2019
Modified by: Natalie D Munro
